contents.ja: リソース公開鍵インフラストラクチャにおける認証局（CA）またはレポジトリマネージャによって有害アクション（RPKI）

contents.text: Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: This document analyzes actions by or against a Certification Authority (CA) or an independent repository manager in the RPKI that can adversely affect the Internet Number Resources (INRs) associated with that CA or its subordinate CAs. The analysis is done from the perspective of an affected INR holder. The analysis is based on examination of the data items in the RPKI repository, as controlled by a CA (or an independent repository manager) and fetched by Relying Parties (RPs). The analysis does not purport to be comprehensive; it does represent an orderly way to analyze a number of ways that errors by or attacks against a CA or repository manager can affect the RPKI and routing decisions based on RPKI data.
contents.ja: この文書では、CAまたはその下位CAに関連付けられた認証局（CA）または悪インターネット番号リソースに影響を与える可能性がRPKIで独立したリポジトリマネージャ（INRS）によって、または反対の行動を分析します。分析は、影響を受けるINRホルダの観点から行われます。 CA（または独立したリポジトリマネージャ）によって制御され、依拠当事者（RPS）によってフェッチとして分析は、RPKIリポジトリ内のデータ項目の検査に基づいています。分析は包括的であることを意図していません。それは、CAまたはリポジトリマネージャに対してによってエラーや攻撃がRPKIデータに基づいてRPKIとルーティングの決定に影響を与えることができるいくつかの方法を分析するための秩序ある方法を示すものでもありません。

contents.text: 1. Introduction
contents.ja: 1.はじめに

contents.text: In the context of this document, any change to the Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) [RFC6480] that diminishes the set of Internet Number Resources (INRs) associated with an INR holder, and that is contrary to the holder's wishes, is termed "adverse". This analysis is done from the perspective of an affected INR holder. An action that results in an adverse charge (as defined above) may be the result of an attack on a CA [RFC7132], an error by a CA, or an error by or an attack on a repository operator. Note that the CA that allocated the affected INRs may be acting in accordance with established policy; thus, the change may be contractually justified even though viewed as adverse by the INR holder. This document examines the implications of adverse actions within the RPKI with respect to INRs, irrespective of the cause of the actions.
contents.ja: この文書の文脈では、INRホルダーに関連付けられたインターネット番号リソース（INRS）のセットを減少させ、そしてそれは所有者の意向に反しているリソース公開鍵インフラストラクチャへの変更（RPKI）[RFC6480]は、 "と呼ばれ、有害」。この分析は、影響を受けるINRホルダーの観点から行われます。 （上記で定義した）有害電荷をもたらす作用がCAによってCA [RFC7132]、エラーの攻撃、またはによるエラーまたはリポジトリオペレータへの攻撃の結果であり得ます。罹患INRSを割り当てCAが確立ポリシーに従って作用することができることに留意されたいです。 INRホルダーにより有害と見てもこのように、変更は契約さえ正当化することができます。この文書は関係なく、請求権の、INRSに関してRPKI内の有害行為の意味を調べます。

contents.text: Additionally, when a Route Origin Authorization (ROA) or router certificate is created that "competes" with an existing ROA or router certificate (respectively), the creation of the new ROA or router certificate may be adverse. (A newer ROA competes with an older ROA if the newer ROA points to a different Autonomous System Number (ASN), contains the same or a more specific prefix, and is issued by a different CA. A newer router certificate competes with an older router certificate if the newer one contains the same ASN, contains a different public key, and is issued by a different CA.) Note that transferring resources or changing of upstream providers may yield competing ROAs and/or router certificates under some circumstances. Thus, not all instances of competition are adverse actions.
contents.ja: ルート起源許可（ROA）またはルータの証明書が（それぞれ）既存のROAやルータの証明書で、「競合する」ことを作成されたときにまた、新たにROAやルータの証明書の作成は有害かもしれません。 （新しいROAは、新しいROAは異なる自律システム番号（ASN）を指している場合、古いROAと競合する同じまたはそれ以上の具体的な接頭辞が含まれており、新しいルータの証明書は、古いルータと競合する別のCAによって発行されます新規の方は同じASNが含まれている場合、証明書は、リソースを転送するか、上流プロバイダの変更がある状況下で競合する資産収益率および/またはルータの証明書をもたらすことがあります）異なる公開鍵が含まれており、異なるCAによって発行されます。このように、競争のないすべてのインスタンスは、不利なアクションです。

contents.text: As noted above, adverse changes to RPKI data may arise due to several types of causes. A CA may make a mistake in managing the RPKI objects it signs, or it may be subject to an attack. If an attack allows an adversary to use the private key of that CA to sign RPKI objects, then the effect is analogous to the CA making mistakes. There is also the possibility that a CA or repository operator may be subject to legal measures that compel them to make adverse changes to RPKI data. In many cases, such actions may be hard to distinguish from mistakes or attacks, other than with respect to the time required to remedy the adverse action. (Presumably, the CA will take remedial action when a mistake or an attack is detected, so the effects are similar in these cases. If a CA has been legally compelled to effect an adverse change, remediation will likely not be swift.)
contents.ja: 上述したように、RPKIデータに不利な変化は、原因のいくつかのタイプに生じ得ます。 CAは、RPKIの管理にミスを犯すことがあり、それが署名オブジェクト、またはそれが攻撃を受ける可能性があります。攻撃は敵がRPKIオブジェクトに署名するというCAの秘密鍵を使用することができます場合は、効果は間違いを犯すCAに似ています。 CAまたはリポジトリオペレータがデータをRPKIする不利な変更を加えるためにそれらを強制法的措置の対象となる可能性もあります。多くの場合、そのような行動は、有害なアクションを是正するために必要な時間に対する以外のミスや攻撃、区別するのは難しいかもしれません。 （おそらく、間違いや攻撃が検出されたときにCAは、是正措置をとりますので、効果は、これらの例に似ています。CAは不利な変化をもたらすことが法的に強要されている場合、修復は可能性が迅速ではありません。）

contents.text: This document analyzes the various types of actions by a CA (or an independent repository operator) that can adversely affect the INRs associated with that CA, as well as the INRs of subordinate CAs. The analysis is based on examination of the data items in the RPKI repository, as controlled by a CA (or an independent repository operator) and fetched by RPs.
contents.ja: この文書では、悪影響そのCAに関連付けられINRS、ならびに下位CAのINRSに影響を与えることができるCA（または独立したリポジトリオペレータ）によってアクションの様々なタイプを分析します。分析は、CA（または独立したリポジトリオペレータ）によって制御される、RPKIリポジトリ内のデータ項目の検査に基づくとのRPによってフェッチされます。

contents.text: 2. Analysis of RPKI Repository Objects
contents.ja: 2.分析RPKIのリポジトリオブジェクト

contents.text: This section enumerates the RPKI repository system objects and examines how changes to them affect Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs) and router certificate validation. Identifiers are assigned to errors for reference by later sections of this document. Note that not all adverse actions may be encompassed by this taxonomy.
contents.ja: このセクションでは、RPKIリポジトリシステムオブジェクトを列挙し、それらへの変更は、ルートの起源権限（資産収益率）とルータの証明書の検証にどのように影響するかを調べます。識別子は、このドキュメントの後のセクションで参照するためにエラーに割り当てられます。いないすべての有害行為は、この分類に含まれることもあることに注意してください。

contents.text: The RPKI repository [RFC6481] contains a number of (digitally signed) objects that are fetched and processed by RPs. Until the deployment of BGPsec [RFC8205], the principal goal of the RPKI is to enable an RP to validate ROAs [RFC6482]. A ROA binds address space to an ASN. A ROA can be used to verify BGP announcements with respect to route origin [RFC6483]. The most important objects in the RPKI for origin validation are ROAs; all of the other RPKI objects exist to enable the validation of ROAs in a fashion consistent with the INR allocation system. Thus, errors that result in changes to a ROA, or to RPKI objects needed to validate a ROA, can cause RPs to reach different (from what was intended) conclusions about the validity of the bindings expressed in a ROA.
contents.ja: RPKIリポジトリ[RFC6481]は、フェッチとのRPによって処理されるオブジェクト（デジタル署名）の数を含んでいます。 BGPsec [RFC8205]の展開まで、RPKIの主な目標広告費用対効果[RFC6482]を検証するためにRPを有効にすることです。 ROAは、ASNにアドレス空間をバインドします。 ROAは、ルート原点[RFC6483]に対するBGPアナウンスメントを検証するために使用することができます。起源の検証のためのRPKIの中で最も重要なオブジェクト広告費用対効果です。他のRPKIオブジェクトの全ては、INR割り当てシステムと一貫した方法で資産収益率の検証を可能にするために存在します。このように、ROAの変化をもたらすか、ROAを検証するために必要なオブジェクトをRPKIするエラーは、RPが（意図したものから）ROAで表現バインディングの妥当性についての結論を異なる到達させることができます。

contents.text: When BGPsec is deployed, router certificates [RFC8209] will be added to repository publication points. These are end entity (EE) certificates used to verify signatures applied to BGP update data and to enable path validation [RFC8205]. Router certificates are as important to path validation as ROAs are to origin validation.
contents.ja: BGPsecがデプロイされると、ルータ証明書[RFC8209]は、リポジトリ出版ポイントに追加されます。これらは、BGPアップデートデータに適用される署名を検証し、パスの検証[RFC8205]を有効にするために使用されるエンドエンティティ（EE）証明書です。ルータ証明書広告費用対効果が原点の検証にあるように、パスの検証にとして重要です。

contents.text: The objects contained in the RPKI repository are of two types: conventional PKI objects (certificates and Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs)) and RPKI-specific signed objects. The latter make use of a common encapsulation format [RFC6488] based on the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS) [RFC5652]. A syntax error in this common format will cause an RP to reject the object, e.g., a ROA or manifest, as invalid.
contents.ja: RPKIリポジトリに含まれるオブジェクトは、2つのタイプのものである：従来のPKIオブジェクト（証明書と証明書失効リスト（CRL））とRPKI固有の署名付きオブジェクト。暗号メッセージ構文（CMS）[RFC5652]に基づいて、共通のカプセル化フォーマット[RFC6488]の後者のメイク使用。この共通フォーマットに構文エラーを無効として、例えば、ROAまたはマニフェストオブジェクトを拒絶するRPを引き起こすであろう。

contents.text: Adverse actions take several forms:
contents.ja: 有害アクションはいくつかの形式を取ります。

contents.text: * Deletion (D) is defined as removing an object from a publication point, without the permission of the INR holder.
contents.ja: *削除（D）は、INRホルダの許可なしに、出版ポイントからオブジェクトを除去することと定義されます。

contents.text: * Suppression (S) is defined as not deleting an object, or not publishing an object, as intended by an INR holder. This action also includes retaining a prior version of an object in a publication point when a newer version is available for publication.
contents.ja: *抑制（S）は、INRホルダによって意図されるように、オブジェクトを削除しない、またはオブジェクトを公開しないと定義されます。新しいバージョンが出版のために利用可能である場合、このアクションはまた、出版点におけるオブジェクトの前バージョンを保持することを含みます。

contents.text: * Corruption (C) is defined as modification of a signed object in a fashion not requiring access to the private key used to sign the object. Thus, a corrupted object will not carry a valid signature. Implicitly, the corrupted object replaces the legitimate version.
contents.ja: *破損（C）は、オブジェクトに署名するために使用される秘密鍵へのアクセスを必要としない方法で署名されたオブジェクトの変更として定義されます。このように、破損したオブジェクトは、有効な署名を運ぶことはありません。暗黙のうちに、破損したオブジェクトは、正当なバージョンを置き換えます。

contents.text: * Modification (M) is defined as publishing a syntactically valid, verifiable version of an object that differs from the (existing) version authorized by the INR holder. Implicitly, the legitimate version of the affected object is deleted and replaced by the modified object.
contents.ja: *修飾（M）は、INRホルダにより承認（既存の）バージョンとは異なるオブジェクトの構文的に有効な、検証可能なバージョンを公開すると定義されます。暗黙的に、影響を受けたオブジェクトの正規のバージョンは削除され、変更されたオブジェクトによって置き換えられます。

contents.text: * Revocation (R) is defined as revoking a certificate (EE or CA) by placing its Serial Number on the appropriate CRL, without authorization of the INR holder.
contents.ja: *取り消し（R）は、INRホルダの許可なしに、適切なCRLにそのシリアル番号を配置することにより、証明書（EE又はCA）を取り消すように定義されます。

contents.text: * Injection (I) is defined as introducing an instance of a signed object into a publication point (without authorization of the INR holder). It assumes that the signature on the object will be viewed as valid by RPs.
contents.ja: *注射（I）は、（INRホルダの許可なし）出版ポイントに署名されたオブジェクトのインスタンスを導入することと定義されます。これは、オブジェクトの署名がのRPで有効なものとして見られることを想定しています。

contents.text: The first three of these actions (deletion, suppression, and corruption) can be effected by any entity that manages the publication point of the affected INR holder. Also, an entity with the ability to act as a man-in-the-middle between an RP and a repository can effect these actions with respect to the RP in question.
contents.ja: これらの操作（削除、抑制、および腐敗）の最初の3つは、影響を受けたINRホルダの出版ポイントを管理する任意のエンティティによって行うことができます。また、のman-in-the-middle RPとリポジトリ間として作用する能力を持つエンティティは、問題のRPに対するこれらのアクションを行うことができます。

contents.text: The latter three actions (modification, revocation, and injection) nominally require access to the private key of the INR holder.
contents.ja: 後者の3つのアクション（変更、取り消し、および注入）は、名目上INRホルダーの秘密鍵にアクセスする必要があります。

contents.text: All six of these actions also can be effected by a parent CA. A parent CA could reissue the INR holder's CA certificate, but with a different public key, matching a private key to which the parent CA has access. The CA could generate new signed objects using the private key associated with the reissued certificate and publish these objects at a location of its choosing.
contents.ja: また、これらの行動のすべて6は、親CAによって行うことができます親CAは、INRホルダーのCA証明書を再発行しますが、異なる公開鍵で、親CAがアクセス権を持っているにプライベートキーと一致することができます。 CAは、再発行の証明書に関連付けられた秘密鍵を使用して新しい署名オブジェクトを生成し、その選択した場所でこれらのオブジェクトを公開することができます。

contents.text: Most of these actions may be performed independently or in combination with one another. For example, a ROA may be revoked and deleted or revoked and replaced with a modified ROA. Where appropriate, the analysis of adverse actions will distinguish between individual actions, or combinations thereof, that yield different outcomes for RPs. Recall that the focus of the analysis is the impact on ROAs and router certificates, with respect to RP processing.
contents.ja: これらのアクションのほとんどは、独立して、または互いに組み合わせて実施することができます。例えば、ROAは取り消され、削除または取り消さおよび修飾ROAに置き換えてもよいです。適切な場合、有害作用の分析は、RPのために異なる結果をもたらす個々のアクション、またはそれらの組み合わせ、を区別します。分析の焦点はRP処理に関して、資産収益率およびルータ証明書への影響であることを思い出してください。

contents.text: The following sections examine how the actions enumerated above affect objects in the RPKI repository system. Each action is addressed in order (deletion, suppression, corruption, modification, revocation, and injection) for each object, making it easy to see how each action has been considered with regard to each object. (For the Ghostbusters Record [RFC6493], we condensed the discussion of the actions because the impact is the same in each case.)
contents.ja: 次のセクションでは、上記に列挙したアクションがRPKIリポジトリシステム内のオブジェクトにどのように影響するかを調べます。各アクションは、各アクションは、各オブジェクトに関連して考えられてきたかを確認することが容易になり、各オブジェクトの順序（削除、抑制、破損、変更、取り消し、および注射）で扱われています。 （影響は、それぞれの場合に同じであるためバスターズレコード[RFC6493]のために、我々は、アクションの議論を凝縮しました）。

contents.text: 2.1. CA Certificates
contents.ja: 2.1。 CA証明書

contents.text: Every INR holder is represented by one or more CA certificates. An INR holder has multiple CA certificates if it holds resources acquired from different sources. Also, every INR holder has more than one CA certificate during key rollover [RFC6489] and algorithm rollover [RFC6916].
contents.ja: すべてのINRホルダーは、一枚の以上のCA証明書によって表されます。それは異なるソースから取得したリソースを保持している場合INRホルダーは、複数のCA証明書を持っています。また、すべてのINRホルダーは、複数のキーロールオーバー[RFC6489]中のCA証明書とアルゴリズムのロールオーバー[RFC6916]を持っています。

contents.text: If a publication point is not a "leaf" in the RPKI hierarchy, then the publication point will contain one or more CA certificates, each representing a subordinate CA. Each subordinate CA certificate contains a Subject Information Access (SIA) pointer to the publication point where the signed objects associated with that CA can be found [RFC6487].
contents.ja: 出版ポイントがRPKI階層内の「リーフ」で​​ない場合は、出版・ポイントは、各下位CAを表す1つのまたは複数のCA証明書が含まれています各下位CAの証明書は、そのCAに関連付けられた署名されたオブジェクトは[RFC6487]を見つけることができ出版ポイントにサブジェクト情報アクセス（SIA）ポインタを含みます。

contents.text: A CA certificate is a complex data structure; thus, errors in that structure may have different implications for RPs depending on the specific data that is in error.
contents.ja: CA証明書は、複雑なデータ構造です。従って、その構造中にエラーがエラーである特定のデータに応じてのRPに対して異なる影響を有することができます。

contents.text: Adverse actions against a CA certificate can cause the following errors:
contents.ja: CA証明書に対する有害アクションは、次のエラーを引き起こす可能性があります：

contents.text: A-1.1 Deletion
contents.ja: -1.1の削除

contents.text:
A-1.1.1  Deletion of a CA certificate would cause an RP to
         not be able to locate signed objects generated by
         that CA, except those that have been cached by the
         RP.  Thus, an RP would be unaware of changed or
         new (issued after the cached data) INR bindings
         asserted in subordinate ROAs, and the RP would be
         unable to validate new or changed router
         certificates.  If the missed objects were intended
         to replace ROAs or router certificates prior to
         expiration, then when those objects expire, RPs
         may cease to view them as valid.  As a result,
         valid routes may be viewed as NotFound or Invalid.
A-1.2 Suppression

A-1.2.1  If publication of a CA certificate is suppressed,
         the impact depends on what changes appeared in the
         suppressed certificate.  If the SIA value changed,
         the effect would be the same as in A-1.1 or
         A-1.4.3.  If the [RFC3779] extensions in the
         suppressed certificate changed, the impact would
         be the same as in A-1.4.1.  If the Authority
         Information Access (AIA) extension changed in the
         suppressed certificate, the impact would be the
         same as in A-1.4.4.  Suppression of a renewed/
         re-issued certificate may cause an old certificate
         to expire and thus be rejected by RPs.
A-1.3 Corruption

A-1.3.1  Corruption of a CA certificate will cause it to be
         rejected by RPs.  In turn, this may cause
         subordinate signed objects to become invalid.  An
         RP that has cached the subtree under the affected
         CA certificate may continue to view it as valid,
         until objects expire.  But changed or new objects
         might not be retrieved, depending on details of
         the design of the RP software.  Thus, this action
         may be equivalent to suppressing changes to the
         affected subtree.
A-1.4 Modification

A-1.4.1  If a CA certificate is modified but still conforms
         to the RPKI certificate profile [RFC7935], it will
         be accepted by RPs.  If an [RFC3779] extension in
         this certificate is changed to exclude INRs that
         were previously present, then subordinate signed
         objects will become invalid if they rely on the
         excised INRs.  If these objects are CA
         certificates, their subordinate signed objects
         will be treated as invalid.  If the objects are
         ROAs, the binding expressed by the affected ROAs
         will be ignored by RPs.  If the objects are router
         certificates, BGPsec_PATH attributes [RFC8205]
         verifiable under these certificates will be
         considered invalid.

A-1.4.2 If the SIA extension of a CA certificate is modified to refer to another publication point, this will cause an RP to look at another location for subordinate objects. This could cause RPs to not acquire the objects that the INR holder intended to be retrieved -- manifests, ROAs, router certificates, Ghostbuster Records, or any subordinate CA certificates associated with that CA. If the objects at this new location contain invalid signatures or appear to be corrupted, they may be rejected. In this case, cached versions of the objects may be viewed as valid by an RP, until they expire. If the objects at the new location have valid signatures and pass path validation checks, they will replace the cached objects, effectively replacing the INR holder's objects.

contents.text: A-1.4.3 If the AIA extension in a CA certificate is modified, it would point to a different CA certificate, not the parent CA certificate. Thus, there may be no impact on the ability of clients to acquire and validate certificates if the AIA is modified.

With this capability, the parent could replace the INR holder, issuing new signed objects that would be accepted by RPs (as long as they do not violate the path validation criteria). This would enable the parent to effect modification, revocation, and injection actions against all of the objects under the affected CA certificate, including subordinate CA certificates. (Note that key rollover also yields a new CA certificate. However, the new certificate will coexist with the old one for a while, which may help distinguish this legitimate activity from an adverse action.)

2.2. Manifest
contents.ja: 2.2。マニフェスト

contents.text: Each repository publication point contains a manifest [RFC6486]. The RPKI incorporates manifests to enable RPs to detect suppression and/ or substitution of (more recent) publication point objects, as the result of a mistake or attack. A manifest enumerates (by filename) all of the other signed objects at the publication point. The manifest also contains a hash of each enumerated file to enable an RP to determine if the named file content matches what the INR holder identified in the manifest.
contents.ja: 各リポジトリ刊行点はマニフェスト[RFC6486]を含んでいます。 RPKIはミスや攻撃の結果として、抑制および/または（より最近の）出版ポイントオブジェクトの置換を検出するためにRPを有効にするためにマニフェストを組み込んでいます。マニフェストを列挙（ファイル名で）他の署名されたオブジェクトのすべてのパブリケーション点で。マニフェストはまた、それぞれの列挙ファイルのハッシュが指定されたファイルの内容は、INRホルダーがマニフェストで特定されたものと一致するかどうかを決定するためにRPを有効にするために含まれています。

contents.text: A manifest is an RPKI signed object, so it is validated as per [RFC6488]. If a manifest is modified in a way that causes any of these checks to fail, the manifest will be considered invalid. Suppression of a manifest itself (indicated by a stale manifest) can also cause an RP to not detect suppression of other signed objects at the publication point. (Note that if a manifest's EE certificate expires at the time that the manifest is scheduled to be replaced, a delay in publication will cause the manifest to become invalid, not merely stale. This very serious outcome should be avoided, e.g., by making the manifest EE certificate's notAfter value the same as that of the CA certificate under which it was issued). If a signed object at a publication point can be validated (using the rules applicable for that object type), then an RP may accept that object, even if there is no matching entry for it on the manifest. However, it appears that most RP software ignores publication point data that fails to match manifest entries (at the time this document was written).

contents.text: A-2.1 Deletion

contents.text:
A-2.1.1  A manifest may be deleted from the indicated
         publication point.  In this circumstance, an RP
         may elect to use the previous manifest (if
         available) and may ignore any new/changed objects
         at the publication point.  The implications of
         this action are equivalent to suppression of
         publication of the objects that are not recognized
         by RPs because the new objects are not present in
         the old manifest.  For example, a new ROA could be
         ignored (A-1.2).  A newly issued CA certificate
         might be ignored (A-1.1).  A subordinate CA
         certificate that was revoked might still be viewed
         as valid by RPs (A-4.1).  A new or changed router
         certificate might be ignored (A-6.2) as would a
         revised Ghostbusters Record (A-4.1).
A-2.2 Suppression

A-2.2.1  Publication of a newer manifest may be suppressed.
         Suppression of a newer manifest probably will
         cause an RP to rely on a cached manifest (if
         available).  The older manifest would not
         enumerate newly added objects; thus, those objects
         might be ignored by an RP, which is equivalent to
         deletion of those objects (A-1.1, A-3.1, A-4.1,
         A-5.1, and A-6.1).
A-2.3 Corruption

A-2.3.1  A manifest may be corrupted.  A corrupted manifest
         will be rejected by RPs.  This may cause RPs to
         rely on a previous manifest, with the same impact
         as A-2.2.  If an RP does not revert to using a
         cached manifest, the impact of this action is very
         severe, i.e., all publication point objects will
         probably be viewed as invalid, including
         subordinate tree objects.  This is equivalent to
         revoking or deleting an entire subtree (see
         A-4.4.2).
A-2.4 Modification

A-2.4.1  A manifest may be modified to remove one or more
         objects.  Because the modified manifest is viewed
         as valid by RPs, any objects that were removed may
         be ignored by RPs.  This is equivalent to deleting
         these objects from the repository.  The impact of
         this action will vary, depending on which objects
         are (effectively) removed.  However, the impact is
         equivalent to deletion of the object in question,
         (A-1.1, A-3.1, A-4.1, A-5.1, and A-6.1).

A-2.4.2 A manifest may be modified to add one or more objects. If an added object has a valid signature (and is not expired), it will be accepted by RPs and processed accordingly. If the added object was previously deleted by the INR holder, this action is equivalent to suppressing deletion of that object. If the object is newly created or modified, it is equivalent to a modification or injection action for the type of object in question and is thus discussed in the relevant section for those actions for the object type.
contents.ja: -2.4.2は、マニフェストは、1つまたは複数のオブジェクトを追加するように変更されてもよいです。追加の目的は、有効な署名を有する（及び期限切れでない）場合、それはのRPによって受け入れられ、それに応じて処理されます。追加したオブジェクトが以前INRホルダーによって削除された場合、このアクションは、そのオブジェクトの削除を抑制することに相当します。オブジェクトが新たに作成または変更された場合、それは問題のオブジェクトのタイプの変更または注射作用と同等であり、従って、オブジェクトタイプのこれらのアクションに関連するセクションで説明されています。

contents.text: A-2.4.3 A manifest may be modified to list an incorrect hash for one or more objects. An object with an incorrect hash may be ignored by an RP. Thus, the effect may be equivalent to corrupting the object in question, although the error reported by RP software would differ from that reported for a corrupted object. (The manifest specifications do not require an RP to ignore an object that has a valid signature and that is not revoked or expired, but for which the hash doesn't match the object. However, an RP may elect to do so.)
contents.ja: -2.4.3は、マニフェストは、1つまたは複数のオブジェクトの不正ハッシュを一覧表示するように変更することができます。間違ったハッシュを持つオブジェクトは、RPによって無視されることがあります。 RPソフトウェアによって報告されたエラーが破損したオブジェクトについて報告されている異なるだろうがこのように、効果は、問題のオブジェクトを破壊に相当することがあります。 （マニフェスト仕様が有効な署名があり、それが失効又は有効期限が切れていないオブジェクトを無視するようにRPを必要としないが、そのためにハッシュがオブジェクトに一致しない。しかし、RPはそうすることを選択することができます。）

A-3.1.1  If a CRL is deleted, RPs will continue to use an
         older, previously fetched Certificate Revocation

         any changes in revocation status of subordinate CA
         or router certificates or the EE certificates of

contents.text: A-3.2 Suppression

A-3.2.1  If publication of the most recent CRL is
         suppressed, an RP will not be informed of the most
         recent revocation status of a subordinate CA or
         router certificates or the EE certificates of
         signed objects.  If an EE certificate has been
         revoked and the associated signed object is still
         present in the publication point, an RP might
         mistakenly treat that object as valid.  (This
         would happen if the object is still in the
         manifest or if the RP is configured to process
         valid objects that are not on the manifest.)  This
         type of action is of special concern if the
         affected object is a ROA, a router certificate, or
         a subordinate CA certificate.  The effects here
         are equivalent to CRL deletion (A-3.1), but
         suppression of a new CRL may not even be reported
         as an error, i.e., if the suppressed CRL were
         issued before the NextUpdate time (of the previous
         CRL).
A-3.3 Corruption

A-3.3.1  If a CRL is corrupted, an RP will reject it.  If a
         prior CRL has not yet exceeded its NextUpdate
         time, an RP will continue to use the prior CRL.
         Even if the prior CRL has passed the NextUpdate
         time, an RP may choose to continue to rely on the
         prior CRL.  The effects are essentially equivalent
         to suppression or deletion of a CRL (A-3.1 and
         A-3.2).
A-3.4 Modification

A-3.4.1  If a CRL is modified to erroneously list a signed
         object's EE certificate as revoked, the
         corresponding object will be treated as invalid by
         RPs, even if it is present in a publication point.
         If this object is a ROA, the (legitimate) binding
         expressed by the ROA will be ignored by an RP (see
         A-5.5).  If a CRL is modified to erroneously list
         a router certificate as revoked, a path signature
         associated with that certificate will be treated
         as Not Valid by RPs (see A-6.5).

A-3.4.2 If a CRL is modified to erroneously list a CA certificate as revoked, that CA and all subordinate signed objects will be treated as invalid by RPs. Depending on the location of the affected CA in the hierarchy, these effects could be very substantial, causing routes that should be Valid to be treated as NotFound.

A-4.1.1  A ROA may be deleted from the indicated
         publication point.  The result is to void the
         binding between the prefix(es) and the Autonomous
         System (AS) number in the ROA.  An RP that
         previously viewed this binding as authentic will
         now not have any evidence about its validity.  For
         origin validation, this means that a legitimate
         route will be treated as NotFound (if there are no

A-4.2 Suppression

A-4.2.1  Publication of a newer ROA may be suppressed.  If
         the INR holder intended to change the binding
         between the prefix(es) and the AS number in the

3. Analysis of Actions Relative to Scenarios
contents.ja: シナリオへの相対的なアクションの3分析

contents.text: This section examines the types of problems that can arise in four scenarios described below. We consider mistakes, (successful) attacks against a CA or a publication point, and situations in which a CA or publication point manager is compelled to take action by a law enforcement authority.

contents.text: We explore the following four scenarios:

contents.text: A. An INR holder operates its own CA and manages its own repository publication point.

contents.text: Note that these scenarios focus on the affected INR holder as the party directly affected by an adverse action. The most serious cases arise when the INR holder appears as a high-tier CA in the RPKI hierarchy; in such situations, subordinate INR holders may be affected as a result of an action. A mistake by or an attack against a "leaf" has more limited impact because all of the affected INRs belong to the INR holder itself.

contents.text: 3.3. Scenario C
contents.ja: 3.3。シナリオC

contents.text: In this scenario, the INR holder outsources management of its CA to its parent, but manages its own repository publication point. All signed objects associated with the INR holder are generated by the parent CA but are self-hosted. (We expect this scenario to be rare, because an INR holder that elects to outsource CA operation seems unlikely to manage its own repository publication point.) Because that CA has the private key used to sign them, it can generate alternative signed objects -- ones not authorized by the INR holder. However, erroneous objects created by the parent CA will not be published by the INR holder IF the holder checks them first. Because the parent CA is acting on behalf of the INR holder, mistakes by or attacks against that entity are equivalent to ones effected by the INR holder in Scenario A. Mistakes by the INR holder, acted upon by the parent CA, can cause any of the actions noted in Section 2. Actions unilaterally undertaken by the parent CA also can have the same effect, unless the INR holder checks the signed objects before publishing them. A successful attack against the parent CA can effect all of the modification, revocation, or injection actions noted in Section 2, unless the INR holder checks the signed objects before publishing them. An attack against the INR holder (in its role as repository operator) can effect all of the deletion, suppression, or corruption actions noted in Section 2 (because the INR holder is managing its publication point), unless the INR holder checks the signed objects before publishing them. (An attack against the INR holder implies that the path it uses to direct the parent CA to issue and publish objects has been compromised.)

contents.text: 3.4. Scenario D
contents.ja: 3.4。シナリオD

contents.text: In this scenario, an INR holder outsources management of both its CA and its publication point to its parent. The INR holder is most vulnerable in this scenario. Actions by the parent CA, acting on behalf of the INR holder, can adversely affect all signed objects associated with that INR holder, including any subordinate CA certificates. These actions will presumably translate directly into publication point changes, because the parent CA is managing the publication point for the INR holder. The range of adverse effects here includes those in Scenarios A, B, and C. Mistakes by the INR holder, acted upon by the parent CA, can cause any of the actions noted in Section 2. Actions unilaterally undertaken by the parent CA also can have the same effect. A successful attack against the parent CA can effect all of the modification, revocation, or injection actions noted in Section 2. An attack against the parent CA can also effect all of the deletion, suppression, or corruption actions noted in Section 2 (because the parent CA is managing the INR holder's publication point).

contents.text: 4. Security Considerations
contents.ja: 4.セキュリティについての考慮事項

contents.text: This informational document describes a threat model for the RPKI, focusing on mistakes by or attacks against CAs and independent repository managers. It is intended to provide a basis for the design of future RPKI security mechanisms that seek to address the concerns associated with such actions.
contents.ja: この情報のドキュメントは、CAおよび独立したリポジトリ管理者に対してによってミスや攻撃に焦点を当て、RPKIのための脅威モデルを説明しています。このような行為に関連した懸念に対処しようと、将来のRPKIのセキュリティメカニズムの設計のための基礎を提供することを意図しています。

contents.text: The analysis in this document identifies a number of circumstances in which attacks or errors can have significant impacts on routing. One ought not interpret this as a condemnation of the RPKI. It is only an attempt to document the implications of a wide range of attacks and errors in the context of the RPKI. The primary alternative mechanism for disseminating routing information is Internet Routing Registry (IRR) technology [RFC2650] [RFC2725], which uses the Routing Policy Specification Language (RPSL) [RFC2622]. IRR technology exhibits its own set of security problems, which are discussed in [RFC7682].
contents.ja: この文書の分析は、攻撃やエラーがルーティングに重大な影響を与えることが可能な状況の数を識別する。一つは、RPKIの非難としてこれを解釈するべきではありません。 RPKIの文脈で攻撃し、エラーの広い範囲の影響を文書化するだけの試みです。ルーティング情報を広めるための主要な代替メカニズムはルーティングポリシー仕様言語（RPSL）[RFC2622]を使用してインターネットルーティングレジストリ（IRR）技術[RFC2650]、[RFC2725]です。 IRR技術は、[RFC7682]で議論されているセキュリティ上の問題、の独自のセットを示します。
